channel.description: Recent content in TIMM on Dickson Neoh - Personal Portfolio

item.title: Unlocking Edge ML: From PyTorch to Edge Deployment
item.description: info This blog post is still a work in progress. If you require further clarifications before the contents are finalized, please get in touch with me here, on LinkedIn, or Twitter. üöÄ Motivation - Edge Deployment It’s 2024, everyone seems to be talking about complex and larger models. Sophisticated models perform well at specific tasks. But they come with the cost of massive computational power. Typically that’s available in cloud-based environments.

item.title: Supercharge Your TIMM Models: 84x Faster Inference with ONNX Runtime Optimization
item.description: üöÄ Motivation Real time inference speed is crucial for many applications in production. Some could mean life or death. üíÄ Imagine you’re behind the wheels of a self-driving car and the car takes 1 second to detect an oncoming truck. Just one second too late… ‚è∞ And you could end up somewhere heavenly… üëºüëºüëº I hope that shows you how crucial this problem is. Today (2024), ML models are being deployed in all kinds of high-stakes industries like healthcare, finance, and self-driving cars.

item.title: Bringing High-Quality Image Models to Mobile: Hugging Face TIMM Meets Android & iOS
item.description: üåü Motivation For many data scientist (including myself), we pride ourselves in training a model, seeing the loss graph go down, and claim victory when the test set accuracy reaches 99.99235%. Why not? This is the after all the juiciest part of the job. “Solving” one dataset after another, it may seem like anything around you can be conquered with a simple model.fit. That was me two years ago. The naive version of me thought that was all about it with machine learning (ML).

item.title: PyTorch at the Edge: Deploying Over 964 TIMM Models on Android with TorchScript and Flutter
item.description: üî• Motivation With various high-level libraries like Keras, Transformer, and Fastai, the barrier to training SOTA models has never been lower. On top of that with platforms like Google Colab and Kaggle, pretty much anyone can train a reasonably good model using an old laptop or even a mobile phone (with some patience). The question is no longer “can we train a SOTA model?”, but “what happens after that?” Unfortunately, after getting the model trained, most people wash their hands off at this point claiming their model works.
